p: Predictive power of range contraction and abundance decline were particularly high for threatened species in notoriously small-bodied orders like Rodentia, Eulipotyphla and Lagomorpha. In Afrotheria, a taxon where range contraction had a predictive power of 71%, 11 out the 14 threatened species belong to the order Afrosoricida, likewise composed of small mammals such as golden-moles and tenrecs [ 62]. Small-bodied species usually have low dispersion abilities and consequently have more difficulty in tracking climate changes [ 63]. Metatheria, Chiroptera and Primates are generally good dispersers, thus life-history traits (e.g. reproduction age, litter size, fertility rate) are usually factors more important when assessing their extinction risk [ 64â€“ 66], which could explain range and suitability change's low predictive power in these groups.
